quizzes.question: Which command is used to create a view?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Views[/h1]

In SQL, a VIEW is a [b]virtual table[/b] that is based on the result-set of an SQL statement.

A view contains rows and columns, just like a real table. The fields in a view are fields from one or more real tables in the database.

Views allow us to:
- Structure data in a way that users or classes of users find natural or intuitive.
- Restrict access to the data in such a way that a user can see and (sometimes) modify exactly what they need and no more.
- Summarize data from various tables and use it to generate reports.

To create a view: [code format="sql"][b]CREATE VIEW [/b]view_name [b]AS[/b]
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;[/code]
[note]The SELECT query can be as complex as you need it to be. It can contain multiple JOINS and other commands.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to create a view named ''temp'' for students with the highest marks.
[!raw!]
{0} temp {1} 
SELECT id, name, mark 
FROM students 
{2} mark DESC 
LIMIT 10;
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating Views[/h1]

Consider the [b]Employees [/b]table, which contains the following records: [img id="2855" width="100%"]
Let's create a view that displays each employee's FirstName and Salary.[code format="sql" ][b]CREATE VIEW[/b] List [b]AS[/b]
SELECT FirstName, Salary
FROM  Employees;[/code]
Now, you can query the [b]List [/b]view as you would query an actual table.[code format="sql" ]SELECT * FROM List;[/code]
This would produce the following result: [img id="2856" width="100%"]
[note]A view always shows up-to-date data! The database engine uses the view's SQL statement to recreate the data each time a user queries a view.[/note]

answers.text: Views need space in the database to be stored

quizzes.question: Which statement in regard to views is correct?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Updating a View[/h1]

You can update a view by using the following syntax:[code format="sql"][b]CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW[/b] view_name [b]AS[/b]
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;[/code]
The example below updates our [b]List [/b]view to select also the LastName: [code format="sql"]CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW List AS
SELECT FirstName, LastName, Salary
FROM  Employees;[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2857" width="100%"]
You can delete a view with the DROP VIEW command. [code format="sql"][b]DROP VIEW[/b] List;[/code]
